title: 115_hr1368
content: The "Animal Welfare Accountability and Transparency Act" may be cited as the short title. It focuses on the public availability of regulatory records. The "Animal Welfare Accountability and Transparency Act" requires the Secretary of Agriculture to maintain and provide public access to inspection reports and enforcement actions related to the Animal Welfare Act and the Horse Protection Act in a searchable online database. The "Animal Welfare Accountability and Transparency Act" mandates the Secretary of Agriculture to disclose inspection reports and enforcement actions for the Animal Welfare Act and the Horse Protection Act in an online database, including details of licensed facilities and individuals. The Department of Agriculture licenses individuals to promote horses through various activities that advance the horse industry. SEC. 3. Use of alternative depreciation system for taxpayers violating certain animal protection rules. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include new provisions regarding property placed in service by a disqualified taxpayer during an applicable period. The term "disqualified taxpayer" is defined as a taxpayer who has been assessed a civil penalty under section 19(b) of the code. The curr_chunk discusses penalties under the Animal Welfare Act and the Horse Protection Act for individuals who have been convicted or assessed civil penalties. The curr_chunk explains that individuals convicted under certain acts will be treated as a single taxpayer for penalty purposes for a 5-taxable-year period after the final judgment. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service in taxable years beginning after the enactment date.
